code:
a, b, c = map(int, input().split())
print(len({a, b, c}))


EXPLANATION:
The code uses the built-in `set` data type in Python, which automatically removes duplicates. By inserting the three paint can colors into a set, any duplicate colors are automatically removed. The length of the set is then returned as the number of different kinds of colors.

The `map` function is used to convert the input strings to integers, and the `split` function is used to split the input string by spaces.

The `len` function is used to count the number of elements in the set.

The input and output are handled by the built-in `input` and `print` functions.

This solution works because sets in Python automatically remove duplicate elements, and the `len` function counts the number of elements in a collection.

The time complexity of this solution is O(1), since the number of operations does not change with the size of the input. The space complexity is also O(1), since the amount of memory used does not change with the size of the input.

This solution assumes that the input will always be valid and in the correct format

This solution assumes that the colors are distinct, as per the problem statement. If the colors can be the same, the solution would need to be adjusted accordingly.

a, b, c = map(int, input().split())
print(len(set([a, b, c])))


This solution works by first reading the three input values a, b, and c. It then creates a set of these values, which automatically removes any duplicates because sets only allow unique elements. Finally, it prints the number of elements in the set, which is the number of different kinds of colors.

The time complexity of this solution is O(1), which is the best possible time complexity because it takes a constant amount of time to execute regardless of the input size. The space complexity is also O(1), because it uses a constant amount of space to store the input values and the set.
